A distributed data-driven coordinated design is proposed to achieve efficient energy management of a residential grid, where controllable distributed resources such as electric vehicles (EVs) and thermostatically controlled loads (TCLs) are adjusted by balancing the end-use electricity cost, charging preference, and thermal comfort. The motivation for the control pattern is to minimize the total system cost by directly utilizing the measured input–output data instead of intractable model identification and state estimation. Firstly, we formulate a data based optimization problem with persistently exciting data sets and show the equivalence with the model-based problem. To protect the privacy of each consumer, we design a distributed pattern by the gradient of the augmented Lagrangian such that TCLs and EVs implement demand response individually. Moreover, the proposed algorithm is enhanced by a receding control scheme to tackle the uncertainties in the predictions. Standard test systems are used to illustrate the proposed design and demonstrate its effectiveness and benefits in the residential community. 2000 MSC 0000 1111 Keywords Energy management Data-driven approach Distributed control Residential area Demand response Nomenclature Abbreviations TCL Thermostatically controlled load. ES n , t ev , d Discharging state of EV n at time slot t . 1 Introduction Integrated with distributed generation, controllable and responsive demands, advanced communication and management technologies, residential areas where rational users expect efficient energy consumption are gaining popularity due to the advantages of their high reliability, efficiency and sustainability [1,2]. It induces energy management problems that coordinate controllable and flexible components in residential areas at both supply and demand sides under economic and environmental goals. For example, the authors in [3] develop a dynamic matheuristic method for the home energy management system to minimize the overall cost. In [4], centralized and decentralized coordination methods for multiple smart homes are investigated. In [5], based on a satisfaction model related to the residential users’ preferences, a multi-objective optimization problem is presented and a centralized fuzzy decision making approach is applied to reduce the energy cost. An active role for the distributed responsive resources, e.g., EVs and TCLs, are considered on the consumer level. Many works, such as [6,7], are devoted to optimize the temperature adjusting schedule associated with the TCL users’ thermal comfort. Concerning the population of TCLs in the residential community, hierarchical grouping control strategy and distributed pattern are presented respectively in [6,7] to achieve the energy management. With an increasing number of home EVs, the demand response potential in jointly coordinating EVs and TCLs is excavated in [8]. In [9], a game-theoretic approach is designed to achieve the optimal energy management with TCLs and EVs. Considering the demand and supply uncertainties, the authors in [10] develop a multi-objective risk-based robust optimization approach to guarantee the robustness and flexibility of the system. The above works are all based on the simplified physical model, which neglect the complex thermal conversions in the buildings. To obtain a more precise expression of the thermal dynamics, many data-driven approaches are introduced in the energy management process [11]. The authors in [12] propose a model-free method based on the human–machine reinforcement learning framework to optimize the TCLs and EVs strategies. In [13], a data-driven model predictive control scheme is devised based on the random forests method, and a modified generative adversarial network is presented to achieve the data-driven management strategy in [14]. However, the data-driven methods are lack of the interpretability compared to the model-based method. Considering the complex thermal evolution in the buildings, in this work, we propose a data-driven approach to achieve the energy management of the residential area. Besides, we construct an explicable relationship between the data-driven approach and model-based method to solve the unexplainability of the traditional data-driven methods. To be specific, we utilize the historical data trajectory to formulate the energy management problem with TCLs and EVs on the basis of the behavioral system theory [15]. The data based expression is equivalent to the state-space model, which could be strictly demonstrated. Then, to overcome the high computational burden of the high-dimensional problem in the residential area, we propose a distributed data-based algorithm and a pre-optimized procedure to make each agent (e.g. TCL and EV) work individually and protect its privacy. The main contributions of this paper could be summarized as follows: c1) A residential area’s energy management problem considering TCLs and EVs is formulated, which makes a trade-off among the end-use electricity cost, thermal discomfort cost and battery degradation cost without violating the feeder’s capacity constraints in the distribution network; c2) An explicable data driven expression based on the behavioral system theory is designed to describe the actions of TCLs and EVs, which is shown to be equivalent to the model-based problem with persistently exciting data sets; c3) A distributed algorithm by the gradient of the augmented Lagrangian is devised to achieve the individual control and a pre-optimized process is incorporated to accelerate the iterative procedure; c4) A real-time scheme based on the predictive control is designed to accommodate the inaccurate predictions and some test systems in different scenes are presented to demonstrate the optimality, efficiency and scalability of the proposed algorithm. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. An energy management model in the residential area is formulated in Section 2, and in Section 3 a distributed data-driven approach is proposed based on input–output data. Section 4 demonstrates the proposed algorithm in typical power networks and the conclusions are given in Section 5. 2 Problem formulation In this work, we consider a residential grid containing a set of buildings and EVs, which is supplied by a reliable radical distribution network as displayed in Fig. 1 . The objective of this paper is to achieve the optimal energy management minimizing the total system cost over a finite horizon T ≜ { 1 , ⋯ , N T } . In each building, it contains various kinds of appliances, including refrigerators, televisions, lamps, washing machines and air conditioners etc. Among those appliances, we consider TCLs such as air conditioners as flexible loads, which could be adjusted according to consumers’ preferences. The rest of appliances are fixed loads and cannot be adjusted. Besides, EVs could charge and discharge in schedule during its plug-in period. Hence, we assume the demand except TCLs and EVs as the base load at each node, which could be predicted preliminarily, denoted by P uc . 2.1 Objective function In this work, the total system cost over the time horizon T contains three parts, the aggregated end-use cost, the discomfort cost of TCL users and the battery degradation cost of EVs. 2.1.1 End-use electricity cost The aggregated end-use cost is associated with the total power demand in the distribution network. Denote P o , t c , P o , t uc the controllable and uncontrollable node power at time t respectively. Similar with [16], we consider a quadratic form to express the whole end-use electricity cost at any time t by (1) Φ 1 , t = a ( ∑ o ∈ O ( P o , t c + P o , t uc ) ) 2 + b ∑ o ∈ O ( P o , t c + P o , t uc ) , with properly valued parameters a and b. 2.1.2 Thermal comfort of TCLs To capture the occupants’ comfort level according to the variation of the room temperatures, we introduce a dissatisfied cost to quantify the TCL consumers’ discomfort level. Note that the TCL in this work mainly focus on the space heaters and air conditioners, which have heavily effects on the room temperatures. For each TCL user m ∈ M s in the s-th building at any time t ∈ T , the cost is decided by the deviation between the temperature of the room (denoted by T m , s , t tcl ) and the most expected set-point temperature (denoted by θ m , t set ) similar with [17], such that, (2) Φ 2 , t = ∑ s ∈ S ∑ m ∈ M s ρ m , t ( T m , s , t tcl - θ m , t set ) 2 , where ρ m , t represents the sensitivity to the deviation from the set-point temperature. With a larger ρ m , the system needs to pay more to the consumers’ discomfort. Note that, the square form used here is the intuitive description that the dissatisfied cost increases quickly as the deviation grows. Any other forms which are twice differentiable can also be employed by our proposed algorithm which will be described later. Furthermore, the set-point temperature θ m , t set and the sensitivity factor ρ m , t at any time t could change according to the occupants’ preferences and behaviors. 2.1.3 EVs degradation cost To alleviate the effect of the battery degradation, we also consider the degradation cost of EVs in this paper. A quadratic-form local cost with respect to the charging and discharging behaviors is also introduced [18] to reflect the characteristics of EVs, such that, (3) Φ 3 , t = ∑ n ∈ N ξ n P n , t e v , c 2 + P n , t e v , d 2 + ζ n P n , t e v , c + P n , t e v , d + 2 ∊ n , where P n , t ev , c and P n , t ev , d represent the charging power and discharging power of EV n at any time t, respectively. The parameters ξ n , ζ n and ∊ n are determined by EVs users’ preferences and known in prior at the beginning of the time. 2.2 Building thermal dynamics In the literature, thermal resistance–capacitance (RC) models are widely adopted to describe the buildings dynamics [19,20]. In this work, to model the diversity of the thermal evolution in different rooms/zones of each building, we use a linear state-space model to express the variation of the multi-zone temperature in each building. Denote the building sector in the residential area by S ≜ { 1 , 2 , ⋯ , N S } with N S ⩽ N M , where N M represents the number of TCLs. The linearized model is derived from the bi-linear model and the effectiveness of the model is validated by the building simulation BRCM toolbox in [21]. 2.3 Electric vehicle model The residential area also supplies a set of EVs whose charging actions could be coordinated by determining the charging/discharging power at each instant. And the values could be adjusted according to the system’s preferences. 3 Data driven energy management The energy management problem specified in Problem 1 is intractable in the case that the state dynamics given in (4) cannot be fully measured, e.g. the thermal dynamics of the mass in the building is hard to achieve. Also, the binary variables appeared in (9)-(11) cause a high computational cost with an increasing number of EVs. And the underlying temporally coupled constraints (4) and (6), and the spatially coupled constraint (12) bring challenges in the design of the control center with computation and privacy problem. In this section, a distributed data driven algorithm is designed to solve the above problems. As illustrated in Fig. 2 , by the previous actions of TCLs and EVs exchanged through the information center, each agent makes its decision simultaneously in a decentralized way (which protects its privacy). Firstly, based on the behavioral system theory, Problem 1 is reformulated as a data based Linear Programming (LP) problem with only historical input–output data of TCLs and EVs. Then, a distributed algorithm is proposed and a pre-optimized process is incorporated to overcome the spatial and temporal couplings in the optimization problem, which makes each TCL and EV work individually. Considering the uncertainties occurred in the system, we extend to a receding pattern to deal with the inaccurate predictions of the ambient temperature and uncontrollable load. 3.1 Data based LP problem By (4) and define T s tcl ≜ col ( T s , 1 tcl , T s , 2 tcl , ⋯ , T s , N T tcl ) , P s tcl ≜ col ( P s , 1 tcl , P s , 2 tcl , ⋯ , P s , N T tcl ) , the control strategy could be rewritten in a compact form, (15) T s tcl ( P s tcl ; T s , 1 b , θ s a ) = Q N T o ( A s tcl , C s tcl ) T s , 1 b + Q N T c ( A s tcl , B s tcl , C s tcl ) P s tcl + Q N T c ( A s tcl , B s tcl , E s tcl ) θ s a , where Q t o ( A 1 , A 2 ) ≜ col ( A 2 , A 2 A 1 , ⋯ , A 2 A 1 t - 1 ) and Q t c ( B 1 , B 2 , B 3 ) has the form of the lower triangular Toeplitz matrix, such that, Q t c ( B 1 , B 2 , B 3 ) ≜ 0 0 ⋯ 0 B 3 B 2 0 ⋯ 0 ⋮ ⋱ ⋱ ⋮ B 3 B 1 t - 2 B 2 ⋯ B 3 B 2 0 . However, the measurement of the initial state including the thermal temperatures of the mass of the buildings is usually intractable. To this end, in the following part, we present a data driven method based on the behavioral system theory which only relies on the control strategy P s tcl and the easy-measured room temperature T s tcl . Based on the behavioral system theory specified in Appendix and then by Lemma 1, the dynamic trajectory of TCL in system (4) could be expressed as a linear combination of the historical trajectories by a vector g s tcl ∈ R K s - T s ini - N T + 1 such that, (16) U s p Θ s a , p Y s p U s f Θ s a , f Y s f g s tcl = P s tcl , ini θ s a , ini T s tcl , ini P s tcl θ s a T s tcl . In addition, the base load profile prediction denoted by P ˇ uc , may also inaccurate. And the above inaccuracy may bring negative effects of the control law, energy loss and even the instability of the system. Hence, in this section, in order to tackle the prediction inaccuracy, we apply the predictive control scheme to achieve a data-based real-time control. Note that the prediction interval is gradually decreasing step by step because of the fixed terminal time N T . In each step, only the optimal strategy in the first slot is adopted, and the initial states of TCLs and EVs are updated until they reach the final time N T . To be specific, P s tcl , ini , θ s a , ini and T s tcl , ini in (16) for all the buildings s ∈ S , and SOC n , 1 ev specified in (17) for all EVs n ∈ N , will be updated by the most recent measurements during the implement procedure. The whole procedure is shown in Algorithm2 and it can be shown that the data-based predictive control is equivalent to the model predictive control (MPC)[26] [Theorem 5.1]. Algorithm 2 Predictive control scheme 1: Set t = 1 ; 2: while t ⩽ N T do 3: Solve (20) for P m tcl , † and P n ev , † w.r.t. the predicted profile ( θ ˇ s , N T - t + 1 | t a , P ˇ N T - t + 1 | t uc ) by Algorithm1; 4: Implement the first step strategies P m , s , t tcl , † for all m ∈ M s , s ∈ S and P n , t ev , † for all n ∈ N ; 5: t : = t + 1 ; 6: Update P s tcl , ini , θ s a , ini and T s tcl , ini in (16) for all s ∈ S by the most recent measurement; 7: Update the initial state SOC n , t ev for all n ∈ N . 8: end while 4 Case studies In this section, several case studies are given to show the effectiveness of the proposed distributed data-based method. As a start, we implement the proposed method in an IEEE 5-node test system and show the equivalence with the physical model based method. Then, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the distributed method and show the real-time control scheme w.r.t uncertain predictions. At last, the scalability is demonstrated by IEEE 13, 33, and 123-node test systems. 4.1 Parameter settings and data preparation We consider a 24-h time horizon T which is from 12:00 AM on one day to 12:00 AM on the next day. Consider the length of each time slot, denoted by Δ T , as 1 h. As shown in Fig. 3 , five residential load profiles in different time of the year are considered as the predicted base load at each node to reflect the characteristics of residential power consumption, which are selected from the real data sets of UK national grid in 2019 [27]. The feeder capacity constraints are displayed in Table 1 . There exists 50 EVs and 10 buildings connected at each node. Each building can be divided into 7 zones equipped with TCLs with different rated cooling power, i.e., [12.15 10.94 14.58 3.55 9.46 14.24 6.08]kW. The building thermal model specified in (4) is produced by BRCM toolbox and linearized by the regression method [22] with 179 states. The battery capacity of each EV is 25 kW. And the minimum and maximum value of SOC are 0.2 and 0.9 respectively. And the charging and discharging efficiency are 95% and 90% respectively. In practice, it is difficult to fetch the EV users’ behavior, thus, in this work, the uniform distributions U [ 16 : 00 , 20 : 00 ] and U [ 6 : 00 , 8 : 00 ] , as mentioned in [28], are adopted to randomly generate the arrival times and departure times. In addition, heterogeneous TCLs and EVs parameters are also considered. The initial and expected SOCs of all EVs are uniformly sampled from the range [ 20 % , 40 % ] and [ 80 % , 90 % ] , respectively. And the initial temperature of each TCL is randomly sampled from the range [ 23.2 , 24.3 ] ∘ C . The trade-off parameters are set as ω 1 = 0.8 and ω 2 , 3 = 0.1 and the energy cost parameters of the electricity price are a = 10 - 5 and b = 0.02 [18]. The TCL’s dissatisfaction cost and the EV’s degradation cost are specified as Φ 2 , t m = 50 ( y m , t - θ m , t set ) 2 with θ m , t set = 23 ∘ C and Φ 3 , t n = 0.004 P n , t ev , c 2 + P n , t ev , d 2 + 0.075 P n , t ev , c + P n , t ev , d + 0.006 . Besides, for the data-based method, given 7200 consecutive inputs to the linearized building thermal model, the historical sets P ∼ s tcl , T ∼ s tcl , θ ∼ s a , ∀ s ∈ S specified in (2) are constructed by the 7200 inputs, measured outputs and ambient temperatures, respectively. And we apply the same procedure in [26] to find the optimal length of the historical data K s = 500 and the length of the initial sequence T s ini = 4 . All the methods in the following cases are solved by MATLAB software and solved on Windows 10 64-bit system with an Intel Core i9-9900 K processor with 16 GB RAM. 4.2 Equivalence with the model-based method In this part, to show the effectiveness of the proposed data-based control (DBC) method and the equivalence with the physical model-based method, we introduce the other two methods as comparisons, i.e., the physical model based method (MBC) and the model based control with a maximum model inaccuracy of 0.5% (MBCI). To be specific, for the MBC method, we solve Problem 1 with the accurate physical model displayed in (4). And in the MBCI method, we considering the identification errors of the model parameters A s tcl , B s tcl , E s tcl , and C s tcl are limited in a certain range by 0.5%. Based on the historical data set ( P ∼ s tcl , T ∼ s tcl , θ ∼ s a ) and the T s ini -length initial sequence ( P s tcl , ini , θ s a , ini , T s tcl , ini ) , ∀ s ∈ S , we apply Algorithm1 to achieve the data-based control (DBC) method. From the perspective of the system cost, as shown in Table 2 , the DBC method is almost identical with the MBC method with only 0.09% error, which indicates that the DBC method could capture the real thermal dynamic evolution. However, with an inaccurate model estimation, i.e., a 0.5% model inaccuracy, the system cost increases approximately 22% compared to the MBC method. Note that the system cost of the MBCI method is an average value of 1000 random trials. In addition, the aggregated strategy obtained by the MBC and DBC methods at each time slot are displayed respectively in Fig. 4 . The aggregated strategy is the sum of the base demand, EV charging and discharging power, and TCL cooling power. And the end-use electricity cost, comfort cost, and EV degradation cost optimized by DBC method are 7829.5, 3223.2 and 342.8 respectively. Obviously, during the whole time horizon, the aggregated strategy of the DBC method just have a slight difference compared to the MBC method. As a result, the proposed DBC method could have almost the same effects compared to the physical model based method. Thus, in reality, if a perfect model of the thermal dynamics is impossible, the proposed DBC method will be better than giving an inaccurate estimation. 4.3 Effectiveness of the distributed data-based methods With the increasing number of TCLs and EVs, centralized data-based methods will have high computational cost. Thus, in this section, we apply the distributed data-based method (DDBC) specified in Algorithm1, and show its effectiveness by comparing with the DBC method. Furthermore, to accelerate the iterative procedures, a pre-optimized distributed data based method (P-DDBC) is also shown in ths part. To be specific, based on the historical information including the historical data set and the initial operation sequence, each TCL and EV implements Algorithm1 individually under the communication topology displayed in Fig. 2, to achieve the optimal scheduling strategy. As a result, the EVs and TCLs’ optimized power demand obtained by the proposed DDBC method are the same with the DBC method, as illustrated in Fig. 4. For clarity, we introduce a normalized value β ‾ l to represent the feeder capacity constraints, such that, (29) β ‾ l ≜ ( P l , t c + P l , t uc ) / β l , ∀ l , t . Then, the satisfactions of the feeder constraints are illustrated in Fig. 5 . And the evolutions of the TCLs’ room temperature and the selected EVs SOC evolution are displayed in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7 , respectively. In addition, we apply a pre-optimized process in Algorithm1 to accelerate the iterative procedure. The iterative procedures of the proposed methods are displayed in Fig. 8 . Due to the dimensional reduction of the decision variables g tcl , compared to the DDBC method, the P-DDBC method converges to the optimal solution at almost the same step but with low computational cost. As shown in Table 3 , after the offline computation by the P-DDBC method, the average solve time of each iterative step decreases almost 80%. And the strategy obtained by the P-DDBC method is coincide with the DBC method and has only a 0.01% deviation in the system cost. 4.4 Real-time control w.r.t uncertainties In reality, the predicted values, such as the ambient temperature and base load, are not always accurate. Hence, in this part, the maximum inaccuracy of the ambient temperature is set to be 3 ∘ C and the fluctuation of the base load is 2%, to demonstrate the effectiveness of the real-time control. By implementing the predictive control scheme specified in Section 3.3, at each time slot, we update the most recent measurement of TCLs’ room temperature T tcl , ambient temperature θ a and EVs’ battery state SOC ev , to achieve the real-time control until the final time. The optimal real-time control strategy is illustrated in Fig. 9 . 4.5 Scalability Three test systems (IEEE 13, 33, and 123-node) are used in this part to show the scalability of the proposed methods. For comparison, our DBC, DDBC and P-DDBC methods are implemented with the same parameter settings and historical data sets. All the methods are solved in parallel with 4 threads. As illustrated in Table 3, as the size of the system grows, the computation time of the centralized method DBC sharply increases since all the burden is centered on the centralized controller. After the 33-node system, the DBC method may not be appropriate for solving the problem. By contrast, as illustrated in Fig. 10 , the distributed methods DDBC and P-DDBC could not only protect the privacy of the consumers, but also reduce the computation cost. Node that we shift the 4-thread computation time to individual controller’s sides by dividing the node number. In addition, the parallel computation time displayed in Fig. 10 implies that the P-DDBC method has a clear advantage compared to the DDBC method on the computation time. 5 Conclusions and ongoing researches In this paper, we have proposed a distributed data-based method to schedule TCLs and EVs to achieve efficient energy management in a residential area. Instead of relying on the model-based control pattern, the proposed data-based method is able to minimize the system cost based on historical input and output data. In addition, we have provided a distributed iterative procedure for its implementation, and a pre-optimized data-based method is shown to reduce the computation cost. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithms was corroborated using standard test systems, and its scalability was validated by more complex systems. In addition, we would like to extend the results in this work to stochastic cases which consider the stochastic process of EVs’ arrivals and departures. In the meantime, we will explore a data-based representation to precisely describe the occupants’ behaviors to achieve the residential energy management. Appendix A Behavioral system theory We firstly introduce some definitions and lemmas concerning the behavioral system theory. Definition 1 (The lag of the system [29]) For an n-order state space system, the system’s lag is the smallest integer that makes the rank of the observability matrix be n. For example, considering the system specified in (4), the system’s lag s l is the smallest integer that make the rank of the matrix Q N T o ( A s tcl , C s tcl ) be s x . Definition 2 (Persistently exciting of order R) Let R , K ∈ Z ⩾ 0 and K ⩾ R . The input trajectory u is persistently exciting of order R if the Hankel martix (A.1) H R ( u ) ≜ u 1 u 2 ⋯ u K - R + 1 u 2 u 3 ⋯ u K - R + 2 ⋮ ⋮ ⋱ ⋮ u R u R + 1 ⋯ u K is of full row rank, i.e., the input trajectory of the TCL is sufficiently long and rich. Next, we describe the TCLs’ dynamics by the historical data of the TCLs’ cooling strategies P ∼ s tcl , the room average temperature T ∼ s tcl and the ambient temperature θ ∼ s a . Here we use ‘tilde’ to indicate the above trajectories are data sets measured from the real system, which are of length K s . Then, we reconstruct them into the following Hankel matrices, (2) U s p U s f ≜ H T s ini + N T ( P ∼ s tcl ) , Θ s a , p Θ s a , f ≜ H T s ini + N T ( θ ∼ s a ) , Y s p Y s f ≜ H T s ini + N T ( T ∼ s tcl ) . Each Hankel matrix in (2) could be partitioned by two parts, the first T s ini row is represented by U s p , Θ s a , p and Y s p respectively, where U s p ∈ R | M s | T s ini × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) , Θ s a , p ∈ R T s ini × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) , Y s p ∈ R | M s | T s ini × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) . And the latter N T row is represented by U s f , Θ s a , f and Y s f respectively, where U s f ∈ R | M s | N T × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) , Θ s a , f ∈ R N T × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) and Y s f ∈ R | M s | N T × ( K s - T s ini - N T + 1 ) . Lemma 1 [15], Theorem 1 Consider the system (4) , and let T s ini ⩾ s l such that the number of the data satisfying K s ⩾ ( | M s | + 1 ) ( T s ini + N T + s x ) - 1 . If the input is persistently exciting of order T s ini + N T + s x , then any input–output trajectories could be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of the historical input–output trajectories. coredata.dc:description: A distributed data-driven coordinated design is proposed to achieve efficient energy management of a residential grid, where controllable distributed resources such as electric vehicles (EVs) and thermostatically controlled loads (TCLs) are adjusted by balancing the end-use electricity cost, charging preference, and thermal comfort. The motivation for the control pattern is to minimize the total system cost by directly utilizing the measured input–output data instead of intractable model identification and state estimation. Firstly, we formulate a data based optimization problem with persistently exciting data sets and show the equivalence with the model-based problem. To protect the privacy of each consumer, we design a distributed pattern by the gradient of the augmented Lagrangian such that TCLs and EVs implement demand response individually. Moreover, the proposed algorithm is enhanced by a receding control scheme to tackle the uncertainties in the predictions. Standard test systems are used to illustrate the proposed design and demonstrate its effectiveness and benefits in the residential community.
coredata.dc:title: Data-driven energy management in residential areas leveraging demand response
